document.title: South Dakota Social Studies Standards Adopted April 17, 2023

9776C6196EB64586960E50CD66FDBC0B.description:
The student explains the effects of the French Revolution and Napoleonic Empire, including
romanticism, nationalism, liberalism, and socialism. H

F0E4A271F2964DDE8067EA1D7855D83F.description:
The student explains the events that led to the rise of Napoleon Bonaparte, his conquests in in
Europe, and the outcome of the Congress of Vienna. H

E701D7D18D6740F2A32D8DCAF381003B.description:
The student explains the origins and major historical events of the French Revolution,
including the ideas of Voltaire and Jean-Jacque Rousseau, government corruption, the effects
of the American Revolution on France, the role of the mob and a lack of experience in selfgovernment, and widespread violence. HC

7E60E4A29B8845C5970BF23E9275B7CB.description:
The student explains how a free market or capitalist market indicates that laws allow
individuals to possess more goods or currency than they need to survive; and to invest,
produce, distribute, and buy and sell goods and services by making their own agreements with
one another. E

306BF13CBBAF4CB6B18F847ABB30DE83.description:
The student explains the origins and effects of the Agricultural Revolution, the First Industrial
Revolution, and the Enclosure Movement in England, including Adam Smith’s observations on
the capitalist nature of an industrial society. HE

02F6ADF5C65D43A3A63DB8A31334A45F.description:
The student explains the origins, political ideas, historical events, and effects of the English
Civil War, the Protectorate, and the Glorious Revolution, and how England was the exception
to absolutism. H

42C69648ED89426FB6D50788CF79F8E0.description:
The student describes the monarchy of Louis XIV and its effect on other monarchs in Europe in
the form of enlightened absolutism, including in Russia, Austria, and Prussia. H

3BBC323C32574DD2A2793A4D5F361AF4.description:
The student explains the major ideas of the Enlightenment, including the ideas of Niccoló
Machiavelli, Rene Descartes, Thomas Hobbes, John Locke, Voltaire, and Jean-Jacques
Rousseau, and their expression in neo-classical art. H

655A57B1CE1A40D4892E90FB61BC6403.description:
The student explains the scientific method and the major ideas and discoveries of the
Scientific Revolution. H

E1D22E0E04E048FDB86163384721F2D9.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of influential ideas from the Scientific
Revolution, the Enlightenment, and the French Revolution.

7EFE455FAEDA410684D637E008FE65AD.description:
The student explains the political and religious elements to the wars of religion in the 16th and
17th centuries, including the Anglo-Spanish War, the French Wars of Religion, and the Thirty
Years’ War. H

9793A18E3BE74C48B5DA369C7DB1348A.description:
The student identifies the historical figures and features of Elizabethan England and the
English Renaissance. H

347ABD75A05B4E7DBA0CFAE0D99E64A2.description:
The student explains how the Protestant Reformation and the subsequent Catholic
Reformation were reflected in art, architecture, and politics. H

6616C542C0BC4D15977E5F4B30ABCA6B.description:
The student explains the main ideas of major Protestant leaders, including Martin Luther,
Henry VIII and Thomas Cranmer, and John Calvin, and how they contrasted with Catholic ideas
and practices. H

1B9673F39ED841FEB68668B3C24D33E5.description:
The student explains the major cultural features and contributions of the Renaissance in Italy
and Northern Europe in painting, architecture, sculpture, and literature. H

4D51D06A64DE4F559988FA17423AFB9D.description:
The student explains the origins and major ideas of the Renaissance, including a revival of
classical Greece and Rome, humanism, the growth of towns, the model of Dante Alighieri, and
the roles of patrons. H

B96D37F7722E41E3B2B6DE0C226D1730.description:
The student explains the developments and achievements of the high Middle Ages, including
the power of the papacy, the founding of mendicant orders, the rise of universities, and the
major ideas of scholasticism and Thomas of Aquino, Maimonides, and Ibn Sina. H

BD64102C0F2A435BB5E2CBF8D6A2C230.description: The student explains the exchange of ideas and culture between Christians and Muslims. H

6F73976CC59A4F64897F3215871EE5A1.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of influential ideas from the Late Middle
Ages and the Reformation.

B4192441E88D4E19BBCBA0349820F117.description:
The student tells of the Norman Conquest, the rule of King John of England, the signing of the
Magna Carta, and the emergence of parliament. H

59A4D6E3EB394C788CB154603B8B37C1.description:
The student explains the origin of the Great Schism of 1054, the Investiture Controversy, and
the Concordat of Worms. H

92D9F03F26684D08AD9958C5D67FAF8C.description:
The student describes and explains Christian and Muslim art and architecture in the Middle
Ages. H

F871358279D748F8BCB8F76A62BE63FC.description:
The student explains the development and practice of feudalism in European societies,
including the expectations of each class, and of slavery in the Middle East, Africa, and Asia. HC

B6092BF65B4546989AAD8C7C5B6628BB.description:
The student explains the major historical events, cultural features, stories, and religious
contributions of early Muslims, including the origins and role of the Qur’an, the preservation
of Greek thought, and expansions in science, philosophy, and mathematics. H

A88892F9F69B4464B4E46BA9C60837D2.description:
The student explains the major ideas and events surrounding the life of Mohammed and their
historical effects. H

1AB108F435E54609ABF2375441550BC3.description:
The student explains the establishment of monasteries, the practices of monasticism, the
preservation of ancient thought, and their role in the Middle Ages. H

43C5BD84C13849DE8CFD3BD185AA9D27.description:
The student explains the ways in which society changed with the fall of the Roman Empire and
the perpetuation of the Eastern Roman Empire in Constantinople, including the role of
Christianity. H

2DDF9CE7A4CA461AA3C84B5127A90A09.description: The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of influential ideas from the Middle Ages.

FFC0EF4DBB1440E293AE3C55B684A9BE.description:
The student explains the role of the papacy and historical figures in establishing Christianity
and Roman law in Europe and the near east, including the Christian church fathers, Arianism,
the Council of Nicaea, Augustine of Hippo, and Justinian. H

0022706AF3FB45538BFA1C7F6F2D33B5.description:
The student explains the origins of the barbarian invasions and the other factors that led to
the fall of the Roman Empire, including the power of the military establishment, political
corruption, and economic instability arising from opulence. H

70B9219C826B4B758C2DA29B05D2C195.description:
The student compares the religion of the Christians to that of the Hebrews and of polytheist
religions, including monotheism, the Trinity, the belief in Jesus of Nazareth as divine, the
redeeming of a person’s sins, the individual worth of each person, and equal moral obligations
of each person regardless of class or authority. H

126540EB5D2C49EFBD9070A30F3917B7.description:
The student explains the major historical events, cultural features, stories, and religious
contributions of the early Christians, including the origins and role of the Bible. H

0425DB4BBF7E46B1B3318CEBEC35F78B.description:
The student explains the factors that accounted for the Roman Empire’s relative stability and
longevity, including its military organization and tactics, the Pax Romana, decentralized
administration, the taxation system, a standard currency, and the road system. HCE

49728D7D81184262BBE56121E5BADDFC.description:
The student explains the major ideas and events surrounding the life of Jesus of Nazareth and
their historical effects. H

20C63F4163D54162ACE09BE11D9A846D.description:
The student explains the major cultural features and contributions of Rome, including in
architecture, engineering, sculpture, poetry, the Latin language, and the histories of Livy and
Polybius. H

62457AE516954AA4A8CEE394AD4C1286.description:
The student explains the social and political organization of the Roman Republic and the
influence of its governing principles and institutions, including the rule of law, the separation
of powers, ideas of civic duty, and representative government. HC

138097AB9FA54FE8B5D1E7E2F15B257F.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of influential ideas from the Roman
Republic and the Roman Empire.

87197390ADD348BC9C301821EF03DC92.description:
The student tells of the conquests of Alexander of Macedon, the founding of the city of
Alexandria, and the spread of Greek culture in the Hellenistic Period. H

D6D9F45DC6EB4FF895F7A9CA743DFFC5.description:
The student explains the major ideas of philosophers and religious thinkers in antiquity,
including Socrates, Plato, and Aristotle, especially in terms of logical reasoning, truth, ethics,
and politics. HC

1D3798CDFDC9478B87F4F17079DE028C.description:
The student explains the major cultural features and contributions of Athens during the
classical period, including pottery, architecture, sculpture, drama, the Greek language, and the
histories of Herodotus and Thucydides. H

9AAD41E2BDA94941BDFA939A84EE9762.description:
The student explains why the government of ancient Athens may be considered the beginning
of democracy, including the polis, written constitutions, voting, a legislative body, and the rule
of law. HC

1FC88A3F52594E749B0E163BD0B70B72.description:
The student compares the monotheistic religion of the Hebrews to the traditional polytheism
of the ancient world, including the belief in one god, the Decalogue, individual worth of each
person, and equal moral obligations of each person regardless of class or authority. HC

DD950692FAF04704B8B0B2073B7B3628.description:
The student explains the major cultural features, stories, and civil and religious contributions
of the ancient Hebrews, including the origins and role of the Tanakh. HC

39B230F14E9D44D682E6B22F5F4080A9.description:
The student explains the major cultural features, stories, and civil and religious contributions
of Ancient Egypt and Phoenicia, including hieroglyphic writing and the first alphabet. HC

500BC7885BF646D48A0148D652CEB19F.description:
The student explains the major cultural features, stories, and civil and religious contributions
of Ancient India, Babylon, Persia, and Ancient China, including the ideas of Siddhartha,
Hammurabi, and Confucius. HC

4101A5CD546045B98714E80C7578425B.description:
The student identifies the six characteristics of civilizations, which are cities, government,
religion, social structures, writing, and art. CE

B1CA356E1AE34A71B8E3A4B54FDEC36B.description:
The student demonstrates knowledge and understanding of influential ideas from ancient Asia, the
Middle East, northern Africa, and the eastern Mediterranean Sea.

3522D52E4CC6470194ADE1E560C6631B.description:
Major Countries (Cities): Argentina (Buenos Aires), Brazil (Sao Paulo, Rio de Janeiro),
Chile, Peru, Venezuela, United States (New York City, Los Angeles, Chicago), Canada
(Ottawa, Toronto, Montreal), Mexico (Mexico City), Greenland, Cuba (Havana), Haiti

B1E71FE4A3B9486E8AEFFFD1D2C17900.description:
Major Geographic Features: Amazon River, Amazon Rainforest, Andes Mountains,
Cape Horn, Panama Canal, Yucatan Peninsula, Straits of Magellan, Isthmus of Panama,
Rocky Mountains, Appalachian Mountains, Mississippi River, Hudson Bay, Saint
Lawrence River, Great Lakes, Gulf of Mexico, Great Plains

08016D3AC7B2455A89526E84D2D09ED1.description:
The student locates on a map and describes the features of North and South America,
including:

9FCA2873C6DE4AA48D578856835FE69A.description:
Major Countries (Cities): China (Chongqing, Shanghai, Beijing, Hong Kong), Japan
(Tokyo), North Korea (Pyongyang), Russia, South Korea (Seoul), Taiwan

6FCF5898D699458C84953721F4F23BE0.description:
Major Geographic Features: Sea of Japan, Yellow Sea, East China Sea, Gobi Desert,
Himalayan Mountains, Yellow River, Yangtze River, Siberia, Korean Peninsula, Mount
Everest

138416D2217241B9A483FB45227E3726.description:
The student locates on a map and describes the features of northern and East Asia,
including:

A6B5FC2B5DCF467CB42B20EA9EFD9BA0.description:
Major Countries (Cities): Australia, Cambodia, Indonesia (Jakarta), New Zealand,
Philippines (Manila), Singapore, Vietnam (Ho Chi Minh City, Hanoi)

1725E7B8A33A4C069D1ED031303BE256.description:
Major Geographic Features: Australia, Antarctica, major Pacific islands, Coral Sea, Bay
of Bengal, South China Sea, Strait of Malacca, Great Victoria Desert, Great Barrier
Reef, Australasia rainforest, Indo-Burma Rainforest

4C92C340C9A34FAA959B3459331FE1B1.description:
The student locates on a map and describes the features of Southeast Asia and Oceania,
including:

728E0CC21C104A96BE43275C0338EA7D.description:
Major Countries (Cities): Afghanistan (Kabul), India (Mumbai, Delhi), Kazakhstan
(Almaty), Pakistan (Islamabad, Karachi), Sri Lanka

218543EDEEC94E038362110BBF21FD95.description:
Major Geographic Features: Bay of Bengal, Ganges River, Indo-Gangetic Plain,
Northern Mountains, Deccan Plateau, Himalayan Mountains, the Steppes, Indus River

E5B635F6B1734D9AB82928D9C7C890AC.description:
The student locates on a map and describes the features of Central Asia’s geography,
including:

47903F091CB64274BD290214D84A87E0.description:
Major Countries (Cities): Iran (Tehran), Iraq (Baghdad), Israel (Jerusalem, Tel Aviv),
Jordan, Lebanon, Saudi Arabia (Riyadh, Mecca), Syria (Damascus), Turkey (Istanbul,
Ankara), United Arab Emirates (Dubai), Yemen

AD2FE8738B1F4EA697A242EDE23D1E15.description:
Major Geographic Features: Arabian Peninsula, Persian Gulf, Euphrates River, Tigris
River, Sea of Galilee, Jordan River, Caspian Sea, Arabian Sea, Red Sea, Black Sea, Strait
of Hormuz, Gulf of Oman

755DCC4DD3864E3FA6C92AB96BA440E5.description:
The student locates on a map and describes the features of the Middle East’s geography,
including:

2833E3E622EF4306825813BC65FC3825.description:
Major Countries (Cities): Algeria, Cameroon, Chad, Ivory Coast, Democratic Republic of
the Congo, Egypt (Cairo, Giza), Ethiopia, Ghana, Kenya (Nairobi), Libya (Tripoli)
Madagascar, Morocco, Mozambique, Niger, Nigeria, Somalia, South Africa
(Johannesburg, Cape Town), Sudan, Tanzania, Tunisia (Tunis), Uganda, Zimbabwe

C3D6606910D84D2E8134DD262472A635.description:
Major Geographic Features: Sahara Desert, Nile River, Mount Kilimanjaro, Atlas
Mountains, the Horn of Africa, Red Sea, Suez Canal, Cape of Good Hope, Red Sea

197F0BE6CE914381AFFD8FB4E3F06D22.description: The student locates on a map and describes the features of Africa’s geography, including:

1F54DFBF8D624961A9B121036C086CA8.description: The student demonstrates knowledge of world geography. G

719C9594B77A41D59FAD2A6CC807F7A5.description:
The student can identify elements that make up a person’s culture, including political
culture. CG

64BF30DA7D56474A9C720DDE6895D52B.description:
The student can state what a graph or chart indicates about geographic information,
including rainfall, elevation, temperature, and population density. G

3F18B28DEBC046B4956A350AC7DF0E0A.description:
The student can identify the six essential elements of geography: spatial terms, places
and regions, physical systems, human systems, environment and society, and the uses
of geography. G

6C6D03FF3021480E8020D17BE5CE4B01.description: The student can successfully select the appropriate maps for different uses.

BC8332CD46754E3F88AA3E6E9A1928A9.description:
The student can identify the elements of information and distinguish between
different regions.

436ED7B0204B4B12A1DE94EAD1D828C5.description:
The student can state the similarities and differences between a modern and historical map of
the same region. HG

93649EDF0EA241BB8BD461109DCC0921.description: The student can read a map using a compass rose with the ordinal directions. G

EC76D5C40B0149AF9C52D16F9DEF23FA.description:
Building upon skills learned in previous grades, the student learns the skills to complete the following
tasks, completing each task with relative ease by the end of 6th grade.

66F359A44A61463980BDA01E91A113F8.description:
The student can write a persuasive paragraph based on class notes, including a topic sentence,
supporting evidence from history and class, and clear attempts to explain how the evidence
proves the topic sentence. HCE

1F1D6DB644DC4524B246D542912774AC.description:
The student can write an informative essay of 4-5 paragraphs on a historical figure based on
class notes. H

42DD374F9B1646EDA2D4A63380B2EE09.description:
The student can write a narrative essay of 4-5 paragraphs on a historical event based on class
notes. H

C214062CD3D840E298237E0E424DAE9F.description:
The student can make arguments about civilizations that left little or no written record, using
archeological evidence, including identifying elements of the Oceti Sakowin (including select
standards from Oceti Sakowin Essential Understandings 1-5) culture through oral traditions,
written accounts, and primary source information. HCE

F707455CE4FE4D52A11ACDEBBD8637C2.description:
The student can form an argument about what a primary source document is saying and cite
in-text evidence to support the argument. HC

5E4BABD51D4641EA8E1F0AE79A41001F.description:
The student can identify a statement based on an objective understanding of truth versus a
statement based on a subjective understanding of truth. HC

CB7AE24DB87E434EA02743F84971480F.description:
Building upon skills learned in previous grades, the student learns the skills to complete the following
tasks, completing each task with relative ease by the end of 6th grade.

790B0668B0BC4336B63A342D2A183605.description: Influential Ideas in History and Civics: To 1815
